title: Increasing Wealthy Population Buoying France’s Prime Real Estate Market
text:
France’s growing wealthy population paired with improving market sentiment is underpinning growing prices and increased demand for luxury homes in the country, according to a report Wednesday from Knight Frank.



The estate agency and property consultants analyzed prime property—defined as the top 5% of each market by value—in key second-home destinations across France: Paris, The French Riviera, Provence and The French Alps.



More: Seven-Story Tribeca House Headed to Market for $15 Million

Paris came out on top for price growth, with values increasing 5% in the second quarter compared to the same time last year. The report did not give the current median price for a prime property in the French capital.



Saint-Jean-Cap-Ferrat, a small peninsula on the French Riviera with one of the strongest international buyer profiles in the region, ranked second for price growth. Prices grew 2% annually there in the second quarter, the report said.



The French Alps ranked third, logging annual price growth of 1.9% across the same timeframe.



Cannes, famed for its international film festival, was the only area analyzed that logged price falls. Values in the town on the French Riviera dipped 0.1% annually.

“France’s appeal needs little explanation,” wrote Kate Everett-Allen, Knight Frank’s head of international residential research, in the report. “It remains Knight Frank’s No. 1 market for lifestyle purchases and the country’s second home hotspots rank high on the wish lists of the world’s wealthy, but its appeal extends beyond its climate and cuisine.”



For international buyers, France offers good transport links, excellent international schools and a transparent legal system, according to Ms. Everett-Allen. Plus “according to the UN’s World Tourism Organisation it is the most visited country when ranked by tourist arrivals—providing a ready source of rental demand,” she said.



France is now home to over 610,000 millionaires, the sixth largest concentration of any country, and the number is forecast to increase by 22% over the next five years, the report said.
